Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that the FBI discovered bones of young children in the waters around Epstein's private island. There is no evidence or credible sources to support this claim.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no credible evidence or sources provided to back up the claim of the FBI discovering bones of young children on the island.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption that the rumors and conspiracy theories surrounding Epstein's island are true, without providing any evidence to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's verdict provides an alternative explanation by stating that the claim originated from a conspiracy-based junk news website, suggesting that the claim is not true.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is no credible evidence or news reports supporting the discovery of bones of young children on Epstein's island.
Understate: The claim understates the lack of credibility and reliability of the source that originated the rumor, WhatDoesItMean.com, by not explicitly stating that it is a conspiracy-based junk news website.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting the rumor as potentially true without providing any evidence or credible sources to support it.
